quiz.title: Economics: International Trade and Factor Demand

questions.question: The offer curves introduced by Alfred Marshall help us to understand how the _______ is established in international trade.
questions.explanation: Offer curves show the quantities of imports a country demands and exports it supplies at various terms of trade, helping determine the equilibrium terms of trade.

questions.question: Demand for factors of production is:
questions.explanation: Factor demand is derived from the demand for the goods and services they help produce.

questions.question: The producer’s demand for a factor of production is governed by the _______ of the factor.
questions.explanation: In profit maximization, a firm hires factors up to the point where the factor's marginal revenue product equals its price, so demand depends on marginal productivity.

questions.question: Under conditions of perfect competition in the product market:
questions.explanation: In perfect competition, price equals marginal revenue (P = MR), so Marginal Revenue Product (MRP) equals Value of Marginal Product (VMP = P × MP).

questions.question: When average product is at a maximum, marginal product is:
questions.explanation: When AP is at its maximum, MP equals AP. This is because MP intersects AP at AP’s highest point.

questions.question: The want satisfying power of a commodity:
questions.explanation: Utility is the economic term for the satisfaction or benefit derived from consuming a good or service.

questions.question: In the case of a monopolist applying price discrimination, the deadweight loss:
options: will always be higher than in the case of perfect competition
will always be higher than in the case of a monopolist that does not price discriminate
is equal to the total consumer surplus in the case of perfect competition
questions.explanation: With perfect price discrimination, the monopolist produces the socially optimal output, eliminating deadweight loss.

questions.question: In a city, there are two car factories, Factory A and Factory B. Factory A can produce 100 red cars or 200 yellow cars per batch, while Factory B can produce 50 red cars or 150 yellow cars per batch. Which factory has the higher opportunity cost of producing one yellow car?
options: Both factories have the same opportunity cost
There is not enough information to answer
questions.explanation: For Factory A, opportunity cost of 1 yellow car = 100/200 = 0.5 red cars. For Factory B, it is 50/150 ≈ 0.33 red cars. 0.5 > 0.33, so Factory A has a higher opportunity cost.

questions.question: There are 4 consumers in the market for sweaters. Consumer 1 is willing to spend $40 on a sweater, Consumer 2 is willing to spend $35, Consumer 3 is willing to spend $25, and Consumer 4 is willing to spend $20. Each consumer only wants to buy one sweater. If the market price for sweaters is $28, what is the total consumer surplus in this market?
options: It is impossible to calculate consumer surplus in this market without more information about the market demand curve.
questions.explanation: Only Consumers 1 and 2 buy sweaters. Consumer 1: $40 − $28 = $12 surplus. Consumer 2: $35 − $28 = $7 surplus. Total = $12 + $7 = $19.

questions.question: Following an increase in price, which of the following would have the biggest impact on increasing the price elasticity of supply for a typical producer?
options: The business can only operate in its ‘short run’
There are stocks, but no spare capacity
There are stocks and spare capacity
There are no stocks, and no spare capacity
questions.explanation: Stocks allow quick sales without new production, and spare capacity allows rapid production increases—both make supply more responsive to price (higher PES).

questions.question: If the XED between two products is (+) infinity, then the goods are:
questions.explanation: Infinite positive XED means consumers treat the goods as identical substitutes—any price difference leads to complete shift in demand.

questions.question: The need for exchange exists because:
options: Free goods have no opportunity cost
Consumers have both wants and needs
Specialisation and the division of labour exist
Unemployment will fall as a result of exchange
questions.explanation: Specialization increases efficiency but requires exchange—people produce what they are best at and trade for other goods and services.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a positive statement?
options: Falling prices are good for consumers
An increase in the price of houses will affect real incomes
Falling prices can encourage consumer spending
questions.explanation: 'Good for consumers' is a value judgement (normative). The others describe cause-effect relationships that can be tested (positive).

questions.question: A positive statement is one which:
options: Is based on a value judgement
questions.explanation: Positive statements are factual, objective claims about how the world works, which can be tested against evidence.
